Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Anammox in a shallow coastal aquifer - combining in situ stable isotope and molecular approaches to examine controls on rates and communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Groundwater holds a large reserve of DIN (dissolved inorganic nitrogen) with extended residence times. Current analysis suggests that 20% of global DIN conversion to N2 (via denitrification) occurs in aquifers. The PIs will focus their efforts on a newly discovered DIN reaction pathway, anaerobic ammonium oxidation (anammox) that combines NH4+ with NO2- to produce N2. Although anammox has proven to be an important route of DIN loss in many marine systems, it is almost completely uncharacterized in groundwater environments despite geochemical conditions that should promote its activity. The preliminary evidence suggests that anammox may exceed denitrification in N-rich aquifers. The PIs propose to investigate anammox, and its connection(s) to denitrification and nitrification at the geochemical and microbial levels through a series of laboratory and newly developed in situ molecular and isotopic investigations. The overall goal of this study is to address the following questions: 1) Does anammox occur at sufficient in situ rates to warrant its consideration as an important mechanism of N loss during groundwater transport? 2) Are there indicative chemical or isotopic signatures for anammox in groundwater that can aid in its detection and quantification? The proposed work will yield the first reported in situ anammox rates for groundwater and define how microbial nitrogen cycling communities (anammox, denitrification, nitrification) interact in a mutualistic or competitive fashion to regulate nitrogen fate in aquifers.

Broader impacts: The project provides internship opportunities through the UCONN Center for Environmental Science and Engineering (CESE). Graduate student support is provided to UNCW and UCONN. Tobias is in a unique position as Coordinator for the UCONN Coastal Studies undergraduate major to incorporate this work into undergraduate education. The project leverages the UNCW Center for Undergraduate Research and Fellowship and will help support two departmental honors degrees. Research experience for high school students will be achieved within the UNCW "Summer Ocean Ventures" program where participants will help with DNA analysis and graduate students act as mentors. The project will support a public lecture on connecting groundwater DIN contamination to coastal eutrophication as part of UCONN's "Coastal Perspectives" and UNCW's "Planet Ocean" public lecture series. Successful efforts to augment groundwater anammox may result in remediation recommendations that can be transferred to regional managers through the Massachusetts USGS district office.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

This project addressed a fundamental question that spans the geological and microbiological sciences: How does geochemistry and microbial community interaction regulate rates of biogeochemical reactions? We focused our efforts on reactive dissolved inorganic nitrogen (DIN) removal in groundwater because of the increasing DIN saturation of the hydro and biospheres, and its role in declining water quality worldwide. We investigated anaerobic ammonium oxidation (anammox), and its connection to denitrification and nitrification at the geochemical and microbial levels through a series of laboratory and newly developed in situ molecular and isotopic investigations.  The overall goal of this study was to address the following questions: 1) Does anammox occur at sufficient in situ rates to warrant its consideration as an important mechanism of N loss during groundwater transport? 2) Are there indicative chemical or isotopic signatures for anammox in groundwater that can aid in its detection and quantification? 3) What are the subsurface geochemical conditions that promote anammox? 4) To what extent is anammox dependent on, or competing with, other N-cycling reactions (denitrification and nitrification) for substrates?

Intellectual Merit - We examined groundwater microbial communities in different parts of an aquifer that was variably affected by a wastewater contaminant plume located in Cape Cod, Massachusetts (Figure 1).  Anammox bacteria belonging to three different groups were detected in groundwater samples obtained from the contaminant plume (Figure 1). Molecular quantification and laboratory incubation experiments also found ubiquitous distribution of anammox bacteria in a depth profile covering a wide range of geochemical features, including the zones of nitrate and nitrite, ammonium, and nitrogen-deficient with no available inorganic or organic nitrogen. In situ tracer tests revealed that anammox is more active than denitrification in the contaminant plume unless organic carbon supporting denitrification is available (Figure 2). Anammox contributed up to 90% of total N2 production in the Cape Cod aquifer (Table 1). Despite the occurrence of anammox in the aquifer, it is cryptic and leaves little chemical or isotopic indicators of is presence.  Direct in situ measurement of rates and in situ expression of the genes responsible for anammox and denitrification were the best diagnostics.

We clearly demonstrated that anammox was present and active in the Cape Cod groundwater under a variety of geochemical conditions. This is the first study to quantify in situ rates and relative importance of anammox with respect to denitrification in aquifer ecosystems. This study indicates that while anammox rates can range widely, it can be a significant contributor to in situ DIN removal and total N2 production in freshwater aquifers. This work lays the foundation for future efforts to attempt enhancing rates of N conversion to N2 by augmenting anammox.  Indeed the results from the tracer experiment have already garnered interest from the water supply/wastewater sectors.

Broader Impacts - This project provided several opportunities to train and develop multiple students and young researchers.  Three graduates completed their M.S. degrees at University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) and University of Connecticut (UCONN). Six research technicians participated in this project. Four technicians leveraged their training into admission to Ph.D. programs at: University of Toronto, The College of William & Mary, University of California at San Diego, and Virginia Common Wealth University. The research experience and activities of two undergraduates in the project led to their hiring as research technicians. In addition, isotope and molecular methods developed in this project were shared with the scientists at US Geological Survey and Korean Institute for Geological and Mineral Resources to support their research projects examining the fate of nitrogen at the groundwater/surface-water interface.
